statement.tex: %text Find the particular solution, satisfying the given condition, for the following differential equation \[ \quad \frac{dy}{dx} -\frac{y}{x} + \csc\frac{y}{x} = 0 ; y = 0 \text{ when } x = 1 \] \underline\text{Note: $\csc = cosec} %
\\ %text The given differential equation is of what type - \underline\text{linear or homogenous}? %
\\ %text Given that the given equation is homogenous, \underline\text{setting $y=v\cdot x$} will give us which of the following? %
\\ %text Given that \[ \frac{dx}{x} = -\sin v\cdot dv \], what will be the \underline\text{particular solution} $y=f(x)$? %

reason.tex:
%text The way to solve a differential equation depends on what type of equation it is. Hence, we must first \underline\text{classify the equation}.
The given equation is \underline\text{not linear}. For it to be linear, \[ \frac{dy}{dx} + P(x)\cdot y = \underbrace{Q(x)}_{\text{a function of x only}} \]
But \[ \frac{dy}{dx} - \frac{1}{x}y = \underbrace{-\csc\frac{y}{x}}_{\text{function of both x and y}} \]
However, note that %
\begin{align} \frac{dy}{dx} &= \underbrace{\frac{y}{x} - \csc\frac{y}{x}}_{F(x)} \\ \text{where } F(\lambda x) &= F(x) \end{align}
%text
These are the conditions for a \underline\text{homogenous} differential equation. Hence, that is what it must be. %

\begin{align} \frac{dx}{x} &= -\sin v\cdot dv \\ \implies \int\frac{dx}{x} &= \int -\sin v\cdot dv \\ \therefore \log\vert x\vert &= \cos v + C \\ \text{ or } \log\vert x\vert &= \cos\frac{y}{x} + C \\ \text{Now }y = 0 &\text{ when } x = 1 \\ \therefore \log \vert 1\vert &= \cos 0 + C \implies 0 = 1 + C \\ \text{ or } C &= -1 \implies \log\vert x\vert = \cos\frac{y}{x} - 1\\ \therefore y &= x\cdot\cos^{-1}\left(\log\vert x\vert + 1 \right) \end{align}
